body: The promoters of this eclectic dance event promise more than a dozen D.J.'s, ''30,000 watts of pounding bass'' and a 7 a.m. closing time. It sounds promisingly hedonistic, as long as your idea of party music involves the raunchy, walloping, hyper-fast sounds of Detroit ghetto-tech, courtesy of DJ Assault. Or the raunchy, walloping, hyper-fast
title: Ring Out, Ring In, And You Can Choose the Beat; DJ ASSAULT AND AARON LACRATE

body: NEFF--Mary V., formerly of Astoria, Queens on December 22, 2006. She was the first female Bank Manager for Chase Bank at a Queens Branch. Ms. Neff is survived by her sister Frances Pylilo of Greenpoint Brooklyn. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Visitation Wednesday 5-8PM at Cassidy Flynn Funeral Home, Mt. Kisco, NY 914-666-4840. Funeral
title: Paid Notice: Deaths NEFF, MARY V.

body: With the liftoff of Discovery in July, the space shuttle program was back in business, more than three years after flights were suspended because of the Columbia disaster. Two more shuttle missions followed, construction of the International Space Station resumed and a newly ambitious NASA announced a goal of establishing a permanent base on the
title: 2006: THE YEAR IN PICTURES; United, Divided, Embattled

body: TO Southerners like us, the apotheosis of pork is country ham -- the hind leg of a pig that has been immersed in rock salt, hung in a smokehouse, then aged for many months to prosciutto-like firmness. We have hallowed country ham in national magazines, clucked over the decline of its mostly artisanal production and driven close to a thousand miles
title: Fanfare For the City Ham

title: For Designers' Disciples, Home as Homework

title: Quinn Offers Compromise On Developers' Tax Break

body: A drunken driver mistakenly turned onto a Hudson River bike path in Manhattan and drove nearly a mile before killing a 22-year-old bicyclist Friday night, the police said yesterday. The driver, Eugenio Cidron of East Fourth Street, left a party at the Chelsea Piers sports complex and drove his silver BMW down the bike path, hitting the cyclist,
title: Drunken Driver Kills Rider On Bicycle Path, Police Say

title: Challenging a Tax Break For Housing Developers

body: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Iraqi Court Sentences Hussein to Death Three and a half years after American troops captured Baghdad and ended the dictatorship of Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi court set up to judge the brutalities of his 24 years in power sentenced him to death by hanging after finding him guilty of crimes against humanity. title: News Summary

body: Frustrated by having to decide between Alan G. Hevesi and J. Christopher Callaghan, below, in the race for New York State comptroller? body: WIDENING Houston Street in the 1950s left lots of jagged edges where a neat east-west alignment used to be. title: POSTINGS; From Odd Lot to Upscale

body: CBGB may be gone, but the music isn't. title: Where the Beat Goes On

title: The Mini Mayors

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: The highest temperature officially recorded on Earth was 136.4 degrees, registered on Sept. 13, 1922, in Al Àziziyah, Libya. Adel Alakhder, 40, who is from Libya, moved to New York in 2005. He said he remembered how, as a boy, he enjoyed the hot, dusty ghibli winds that descended from the country's inland mountains toward the Mediterranean Sea.
title: Think of It This Way: It Could Be 136

title: Bail Is Set At $250,000 In Big Fire In Brooklyn

body: THE McCARREN PARK POOL in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is surely one of the last places in New York you would expect to see a concert. Shuttered by the city 22 years ago, it is a 50,000-square-foot void, its floor specked with decades-old turquoise paint and its walls blanketed by layers of graffiti. It lacks electricity and lights, and its bathrooms have
title: Dive In, the Music's Fine: Rock Moves Outdoors

body: The investigators went to Zbigniew Sarna's house upstate one afternoon this month, walked past some reporters who had gathered outside and suggested to Mr. Sarna that they go somewhere quiet to talk. There were four of them and they all wore jeans, and Mr. Sarna, a mason in Pond Eddy, N.Y., had complicated their high-profile investigation by
title: Upstate Man Sticks to Alibi for Suspect in Brooklyn Fire

body: The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation yesterday requiring the Environmental Protection Agency to study the effects of a half-century-old underground oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. The Senate has said it will also approve the legislation, and President Bush is expected to sign it as part of a broader maritime bill. The
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Environmental Study For Oil Spill

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg broke ground yesterday on the first housing development to be built under the city's recently expanded inclusionary zoning program, which allows developers to build at greater-than-usual density in return for making at least 20 percent of all new units available for people with low incomes. The development, at 164 Kent
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ground Broken For Housing Development

body: For the last four decades, the predominantly black population of central Brooklyn has been represented in Washington by one of its own, a tradition that dates to the 1968 victory of Shirley Chisholm, the first black woman elected to Congress. But now, in a district whose boundaries were drawn to strengthen black voting power, residents are locked
title: In Shirley Chisholm's Brooklyn, Rancor Over White Candidacy

body: Go East to West End, Young Frodo The London production of ''The Producers'' will close on Jan. 6, making room at the Theater Royal Drury Lane in the West End for ''The Lord of the Rings'' to open on June 19, the BBC and Reuters reported. The new import is expected to cost $23 million, making it the most expensive musical ever staged in London,
title: Arts, Briefly

body: A homeless Polish immigrant accused of burning down the Greenpoint Terminal Market was denied bail yesterday after a judge failed to find problems with a video recording of his statement to the police. The immigrant, Leszek Kuczera, 59, was ordered to jail until July 6, when he is scheduled for arraignment in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. Mr.
title: Man Accused of Setting Greenpoint Fire Is Denied Bail

body: For years, the people of Greenpoint have been waiting -- and waiting, and waiting -- for someone to finish cleaning up the half-century-old underground oil spill seeping through the silt and soil below their homes and into Newtown Creek, the forlorn estuary that borders their Brooklyn neighborhood to the north. Since the spill was discovered nearly
title: Spitzer's Office Takes On Oil Cleanup Case

body: New York has a smaller share of middle-income families than any other major metropolitan area in the nation, and like residents of most American cities and suburbs, they live in a dwindling number of middle-income neighborhoods, according to a new analysis of census figures released yesterday. Only Los Angeles has a smaller proportion of
title: Ranks of City's Middle Class Are Thinnest in the Nation

The Bowl is an indoor skateboarder's pit, and to get there you walk down a moderately gentrified stretch of
title: Dance Review; 'Seriously Heavy,' Dance by Robbinschilds, at Skateboarder's Bowl in Brooklyn

body: Looking rested and even cheery during a jailhouse interview yesterday, the man accused of starting a blaze that destroyed a warehouse complex on the Brooklyn waterfront last month denied that he had confessed to starting the fire and insisted that he had been in upstate New York when it occurred. ''I never told them I did it,'' said the man, Leszek
title: Man Charged in Warehouse Fire Denies Confessing

body: Is indie rock going spiritual? Last year's sensation, Arcade Fire, built an entire album around the idea of the funeral: the regret, the loss, the mystery and the life-goes-on. Now Band of Horses, a new group from Seattle that has a shimmering, guitar-drenched debut album, ''Everything All the Time'' (Sub Pop), also heads to the undertaker's for
title: The Listings: June 16 - June 22; BAND OF HORSES

body: The police said yesterday that they were investigating a claim that the suspect in the May 2 fire that destroyed a historic warehouse complex in Brooklyn was working at a camp more than 80 miles away on that date. The suspect, Leszek Kuczera, 59, told investigators last week that he and another man started the fire at the Greenpoint Terminal Market
title: Investigation of Warehouse Fire Veers Upstate Over Alibi Claim

body: FINDING the entrance of Autumn Bowl, an indoor pit for skateboarders tucked inside an industrial factory on the Brooklyn waterfront, is a bit harrowing -- especially at 7 a.m., when the streets are deserted and the air is still dusty with particles from the fire last month that destroyed part of the neighboring Terminal Market Building in
title: DANCE; Romance Has Its Ups and Downs, And So Does This Unlikely Stage

body: Pepe's Tire Shop in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, fixes flats for $6 apiece and is usually swarming with people trying to get patched up and back on the road. Yesterday afternoon, flats were still being fixed, but a more pressing task was at hand: watching the opening day World Cup match between Ecuador and Poland. Pepe's is in a heavily Polish section of
title: At Tire Store, a Well-Lubricated Rivalry

body: At Pepe's Tire Shop in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, all eyes were watching the opening day World Cup match between Ecuador and Poland.
title: AUDIO SLIDE SHOW; Audio Slide Show: A World Cup Rivalry

body: To the Editor: Re ''$92 Million More Is Sought for Exxon Valdez Cleanup'' (news article, June 2): Last week, the Justice Department and the State of Alaska requested nearly $100 million in additional funds from ExxonMobil for cleaning up the 1989 Valdez oil spill, on top of $900 million already disbursed. Brooklynites applaud this cleanup effort,
title: Toxic in Brooklyn

body: A homeless man charged with starting the fire that consumed a Brooklyn warehouse complex last month was ordered held without bail yesterday, as investigators continued to search for at least one accomplice. Prosecutors, meanwhile, provided new details about the events that led up to the fire. The homeless man, Leszek Kuczera, 59, was arrested on
title: Brooklyn Fire Suspect Is Held Without Bail

body: The arrest of a 59-year-old homeless man on Wednesday who was charged with starting a fire last month that destroyed much of the Greenpoint Terminal Market has drawn attention to an insular group that is a familiar part of the local landscape. For decades, Greenpoint has been home to a substantial number of Polish men who live on the streets. The
title: A Fire Suspect's Companions in the Hard Life of Alcohol on the Street

body: Two homeless men burning the insulation off copper wires they intended to sell as scrap sparked the spectacular fire that ripped through a warehouse complex on the Brooklyn waterfront last month, the authorities said yesterday. Four hundred firefighters fought the May 2 blaze, which consumed at least 10 historic buildings. One of the homeless men,
title: 2 Homeless Men Blamed for Fire On Waterfront

body: Years of alcoholism dragged Leszek Kuczera, a 59-year-old Polish immigrant, from steady work to a life of homelessness, begging and selling stolen copper as scrap metal for vodka money, his brother and friends said yesterday. It was that quest for copper that led him to set the fire on May 2 that grew to a 10-alarm blaze at the Greenpoint Terminal
title: Need for Vodka Money Fueled Fire, One Theory Goes

body: What remains of the Greenpoint Terminal Market is a crime scene no more. With the arrest of a homeless man yesterday who investigators say set off the blaze that destroyed a huge waterfront complex, the owner is now free to revive development plans that could transform the 14-acre site into 2.6 million square feet of luxury housing, some of it
title: Focus at Gutted Factory Site Turns Again to Development

body: An archipelago of sorts, a collection of rock formations dotted with scrub brush, has been home to New York's mental institutions, quarantine hospitals and some of the city's most famous residents. Long abandoned by people, some of the islands have now become home to migratory birds that have flocked there in numbers not seen in decades. The
title: The East River is Cleaner Now. The Water Birds Say So.

body: In its latest effort to reclaim waterfront land for recreation, New York City plans to turn a half-mile stretch of contaminated landfill and crumbled piers in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn into a park with panoramic views of the harbor and the Manhattan skyline. The landfill was created in the 1970's, when the city planned to convert the
title: In the Works, Another Park For a Bit of the Waterfront

author: Ed Morales is the author of ''Living in Spanglish: The Search for Latino Identity in America.''
body: ''THIS is the Bronx I grew up in,'' I said with a sigh to a friend from Puerto Rico. We were at land's end, at the eastern edge of East Tremont Avenue, the point where the Long Island Sound ends and the East River begins. To the left, the long arch of the Throgs Neck Bridge played tag with the sunlight. My friend and I had driven there from
title: His Island City

body: AFTER 28 years in the same rented apartment on the Upper West Side, the actor Mandy Patinkin and his wife, the actress Kathryn Grody, are planning a move. Mr. Patinkin said he would have been happy to stay in the apartment, which was rent-stabilized when they moved in nearly three decades ago. But because of changes in the rent stabilization law,
title: BIG DEAL; Mandy Patinkin Makes a Move

body: Ann Kansfield -- Pastor Ann, as she is known to some parishioners -- has come up with a game to keep the children's attention during services at Greenpoint Reformed Church in Brooklyn. Calling the youngsters to the front of the church, where they sit on steps facing the congregation, she asks if any of them has an object that she can use in the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Don't Ask. Don't Tell. Just Pray.

body: As arson investigators continued examining evidence collected from the scene of a huge 10-alarm fire on May 2 at the Greenpoint Terminal Market, its owner, Joshua Guttman, spent yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on an older and less headline-grabbing matter: the resolution of an 8-year-old lawsuit over an artist's missing equipment. Mr.
title: Controversial Landlord Meets His Match in Brooklyn Court

body: LIFE. Death. Salami. These are the elemental forces that shape each day for Marc Buzzio, one of New York's last and best makers of traditional dry-cured sausages. ''There's no substitute for morbidity,'' he said recently, raising a 12-pound soppressata to his nose. The smell of rot -- the ripe funk you breathe in Italian pork stores and French
title: Kissed by Air, Never by Fire

body: The homely brick building had been a factory, and then a coffee processing plant and a place where street vendors parked their food carts. It became a warren of wide-open loft apartments. Later, it was the center of a lawsuit and the scene of a four-alarm fire, and it still stands, empty and black inside, with padlocks on thick chains looped
title: The Lofts, a Landlord and a Battle to Remember

body: LAST Tuesday, for the first time since the Greenpoint Terminal Market was devoured by a 10-alarm blaze one week before, the streets adjoining the site were reopened. At Oak and West Streets, blue barricades and police tape kept people a few dozen yards from the rubble, and a security guard zipped back and forth in a compact car chasing away anyone
title: Street Level/Greenpoint; After the Fire, Cleaning Up And Coming To Terms

body: Alan Hevesi, the New York State comptroller, intervened last week in a quiet but important environmental struggle over the future of Newtown Creek and the neighborhoods that surround it. His intervention is timely and welcome. Newtown Creek serves as the border between Queens and Brooklyn. It is hard to imagine a more God-forsaken marine
title: Rescuing Newtown Creek

body: If you've ever taken sides in a debate over which New York purveyor has the best smoked salmon, you might be surprised to learn that Zabar's, Citarella, Balducci's, Costco and Wegmans -- in fact most grocers on the East and West Coasts, in the Midwest and even a few in Puerto Rico -- buy their fish in large part from the same smokehouse: Acme
title: The Industry; The Great American Smoke Out

body: As part of their investigation into the fire that devastated a warehouse complex on the Brooklyn waterfront this month, fire marshals turned yesterday to a special investigator -- a 5-year-old golden retriever named Bucca. It was not clear whether the dog -- trained to detect accelerants and sit when he smells them -- had shed any further light on
title: Fire Marshals Bring In Dog to Sniff for Arson

body: When a spectacular 10-alarm fire reduced a complex of 15 historic warehouses on the Brooklyn waterfront to a smoldering pile of embers last week, most residents remembered the buildings as relics that had long ago passed into disuse. Few, it seemed, expressed any regret over their fiery demise. But the abandoned 19th-century warehouses, part of the
title: Hidden Populace Mourns Fiery Loss of 'Forgotten City'

body: WHEN Jeff Koons's giant topiary sculpture ''Puppy'' was installed at Rockefeller Center in May 2000, the three-week-long process involved about 100 riggers, planters, engineers and studio assistants. title: ART; Looks Brilliant on Paper. But Who, Exactly, Is Going to Make It?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Vinyl Underground

title: As Waterfront Smolders, Attention Turns to a Failed Deal

title: All-Day Blaze On Waterfront Scars Brooklyn

title: The Death of Milton Rocano, Unseen, Unnoticed and Horrible

title: Man Found Dead on L.I. Is Thought to Be Recycling Plant Worker

body: Edible Brooklyn, a free quarterly, covers the food scene in its namesake borough. title: FOOD STUFF; From Soup to Nuts, and in Between, in Brooklyn

body: A Manhattan truck driver was fatally injured yesterday when a pile of wood he was transporting collapsed on his head, the police said. The driver, Wei Lin Wu, 36, of 245 Broome Street, was hauling a load of 12-by-2 planks when he stopped to check the wood on Meeker Avenue in Greenpoint. Law enforcement officials said Mr. Wu was adjusting the pile
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Driver Crushed By Falling Timber

body: An article last Sunday about opposing views on restoring the McCarren Park pool in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misidentified a group that staged an experimental dance performance there last year. It was Sens Production, a nonprofit organization. (''Agora'' was the title of the performance.)

body: THE British singer-songwriter Natasha Bedingfield watched herself in an antique mirror as her stylist hovered behind her, tweezing and fluffing her blond hair with the concentration of a maestro. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Seeking to Recapture the Glory of the Past. Or Maybe Not.

title: LIVING IN/Ridgewood, Queens; A Neat Enclave Enriched by Waves of Immigrants

title: THE LISTINGS: FEB. 3-FEB. 9

body: A 25-year-old graduate student was struck and killed by a drunken driver early yesterday in a hit-and run accident as she was crossing a street with friends in Manhattan, the police said. The victim, Hannah Engle, had just seen a movie with her sister and several friends and was heading home about 1:30 a.m. when she was hit at 14th Street and
title: Pedestrian Dies In Hit-Run; Driver Charged

body: At a casual glance, the dusty byways of eastern Greenpoint in Brooklyn do not suggest that the neighborhood is a culinary destination. The main traffic arrives not by foot but by truck, and the area is mostly residential. The Newtown Creek Water Pollution Control Plant, a growing collection of bulbous storage tanks, is the largest landmark.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; A Double Take Amid the Dust: Heaping Plates, A Bit of Home

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: BEING a sociable kind of guy, Otis Hart formed a group of four friends who would all live together. Finding a four-bedroom apartment was easy. Mr. Hart put a $100 cash deposit on the third place he set foot in -- a sunny, soaring duplex that was truly magnificent, as long as you looked beyond the filth, the dog waste and the general vagrant feel. A
title: THE HUNT; Start With an E-Mail to 511 People

body: A sudden wintry chill marked by harsh winds and icy snowfall descended on the New York region over the weekend, downing trees, causing power failures in tens of thousands of homes and apparently contributing to the deaths of three men found frozen outdoors. The storm, which began pounding the Northeast late Saturday, caught the area off guard,
title: Wind and Cold Are Blamed In Three Deaths

body: It was spring, and Irene Ciekielski and Maria Wojakowski of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, who had been best friends since the third grade, were high school seniors. With college looming, they wanted to spend as much time together as they could, and a logical place to do that was the Metropolitan Pool and Fitness Center in nearby Williamsburg. The city-run
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG; Pumping Iron, Getting Carded

body: Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition. title: The Listings: Jan. 13 - Jan. 19

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: AT age 33, Nathan Kipe had outgrown the post-collegiate lifestyle he led in ultratrendy Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He paid just $590 a month for a windowless bedroom in an apartment he shared with two friends. In their noisy industrial building, bands practiced in the hallways at all hours. He knew he could afford a nicer place only if he continued to
title: THE HUNT; Finding a Kindred Spirit in the Search for a Home

body: FOR a man engaged in a fight over turf, Mike Pallotta seems more wistful than combative. Mr. Pallotta, 50, is one of the city's last itinerant cutlery grinders. For four decades, from the time he was a 5-year-old Brooklyn boy riding beside his father, Mr. Pallotta roamed the neighborhoods of New York in his father's green Chevy truck, sharpening
title: CITY PEOPLE; Bells Clanging, A Tradesman Comes Home

body: SHORTLY after Mayor Bloomberg's re-election in November, The New York Times asked New Yorkers to give him some advice -- specifically, practical ways to improve the city at a modest cost but with a citywide impact. The Times then asked city and other officials to assess the ideas as bright, light or something in between. The ideas focused on
title: Dear Mayor Mike

body: HIPSTERS are a little like porn stars: you know them when you see them, but no one wants to admit he is one. ''I'm anti-hipster,'' said Brett Casper, 30, a photographer, before allowing that his choice of neighborhood -- Greenpoint, Brooklyn -- made him a bit suspect. And his friend Polly Cheung, 25, was wearing a train-engineer-style cap and a
title: BOÎTE; Keeping It Real

author: E-mail: dabarry@nytimes.com
body: THE artistic influences of Marie A. Roberts are many. There is Giotto, with his genius for bringing religious subjects to life. Raphael, with his thorough command of composition. Masoccio. Toulouse-Lautrec. Van Gogh. Lionel the Lion-Faced Man. And don't forget Baron Paucci, the World's Smallest Perfect Man. Or the fake Siamese twins known as the
title: About New York; Pictures Of Exhibitions

body: The Greenpoint Hotel is still listed in a few tourist guides, which promise cheap rooms and warn of the brusque if efficient staff. But few map-carrying bargain-hunters stay there these days. The hallways stink of marijuana and urine; the bathrooms -- one per floor -- are caked in dirt, and hot water is rare. The front desk is barricaded shut with
title: Cheap Rooms, and 'a Drug for Every Floor'
